The projection of a vector, such as an input vector, onto another vector, such as a weight vector, is a mathematical operation that maps the input vector onto the line defined by the weight vector. The result of this operation is a vector that is parallel to the weight vector and has the same direction as the weight vector. The length of this projected vector is determined by the dot product between the input vector and the weight vector.

The dot product between two vectors is a scalar value that represents the amount of one vector that is aligned with the other vector. It is calculated by multiplying the corresponding components of the two vectors and then summing them up. The dot product is positive when the two vectors are pointing in the same direction and negative when they are pointing in opposite directions.

In the context of logistic regression, the dot product is used to project the input vector onto the weight vector, which is the decision boundary. The dot product between the weight vector and the input vector is a scalar value that represents the amount of the weight vector that is aligned with the input vector. The sign of this dot product determines which side of the decision boundary the input vector lies on. If the dot product is positive, the input vector is on one side of the decision boundary, and if the dot product is negative, the input vector is on the other side of the decision boundary.

The absolute value of the dot product can also be used to measure the distance between the input vector and the decision boundary. The distance between the input vector and the decision boundary is the absolute value of the dot product divided by the magnitude of the weight vector. This distance can be useful in interpreting the confidence of the classification.
